posts.post_content:
Why is this rated so low? It's a 1/1 for 1 playable on turn 1, a 3/3 first strike for 3 playable on turn 2, and a 4/4 double strike (which is almost 8/8 first strike) for 8 as early as turn 4. Three competitively costed creatures payable in installments is a wonderful card, so I don't see why it's not voted closer to 5.  
  
Also, it's a girl. Stop calling her a "him."

Posted By: SleetFox (4/16/2010 8:24:06 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Don't diss the level up mechanic, man. I think it's a fun and flavourful mechanic that has many cool applications. The Zendikar block has taken inspiration from RPGs like D&D before (in the Adventurer and Quest concepts) so I don't think it's strange that they would introduce levelers to the game. I believe these guys will add to the game rather than detract from it.  
  
This particular specimen is an awesome creature, since you can potentially have a 3/3 First Strike swinging on turn 2! As the game goes on, he'll remain relevant as a mana-sink for when you have no plays. Then, he becomes a 4/4 Double Strike late-game, which is quite amazing to be honest. I like levelers in general because they can remain relevant throughout the game, instead of being quick and dirty 1 or 2 drops that lose their place in the spotlight as soon as bigger creatures make their way onto the battlefield.
posts.html:

I believe these guys will add to the game rather than detract from it.

This particular specimen is an awesome creature, since you can potentially have a 3/3 First Strike swinging on turn 2! As the game goes on, he'll remain relevant as a mana-sink for when you have no plays. Then, he becomes a 4/4 Double Strike late-game, which is quite amazing to be honest. I like levelers in general because they can remain relevant throughout the game, instead of being quick and dirty 1 or 2 drops that lose their place in the spotlight as soon as bigger creatures make their way onto the battlefield.

Posted By: StriderHiryu (4/26/2010 4:16:26 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
T1 this  
T2 Level 2, 3 FS damage  
T3 [Time of Heroes](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Time of Heroes), Level 3, 5 FS damage  
T4 Level 7, 12 DS damage.  
  
Great against midrange decks, and what I like the most about all the levelers is they each pack a seperate stage of threats that the opponent will have to pace their mana in order to deal with. (For example, [Lightning Bolt](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lightning Bolt) can deal with this levels 1-6, but once it's at 7, it can be pretty difficult to deal with since it makes that once-desired Bolt a dead draw.  
  
Love this. Want 4, now.
posts.html:

Love this. Want 4, now.

Posted By: Aun (4/22/2010 7:32:06 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: My issue with Level Up isn't the flavor of it. As the creatures of Zendikar battle fight the Eldrazi, it makes sense that they would learn a few new tricks over time. However, most of the cards with the effect are completely useless outside of Limited, due to their high costs for Level Up. Why spend all your mana early game on something that will get hit with a terminate/Doomblade/PTE/Vampire Hexmage/Malestrom pulse/O-ring/Journey to Nowhere/Vendetta/maybe lightning bolt/anything I miss?/ when it tries to attack? Student of Warfare is an exception, rather than the rule. Joraga Treespeaker is one of the few other ones.
posts.html:
